sn22.47:4.2: “Mendicants, whatever ascetics and brahmins regard various kinds of things as self, all regard the five grasping aggregates, or one of them.
sn22.47:4.4: It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They regard form as self, self as having form,
sn22.47:4.5: form in self, or self in form.
sn22.47:4.9: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness,
sn22.47:4.10: consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
sn22.47:5.1: So they’re not rid of this way of regarding things and the construct ‘I am’.
sn22.47:5.2: As long as they’re not rid of the construct ‘I am’, the five faculties are conceived—
sn22.47:5.3: the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.
sn22.47:5.4: The mind, phenomena, and the element of ignorance are all present.
sn22.47:5.5: Struck by feelings born of contact with ignorance, an uneducated ordinary person thinks ‘I am’,
sn22.47:5.13: ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient’.
sn22.47:6.1: The five faculties stay right where they are.
sn22.47:6.2: But an educated noble disciple gives up ignorance about them and gives rise to knowledge.
sn22.47:6.3: With the fading away of ignorance and the arising of knowledge, they don’t think ‘I am’,
sn22.47:6.11: ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient’.”
